page.title: 02LOCAL AGRICULTURE: RANBY(1)
page.content: Until the late eighteenth century much of the land lay in waste or in commons that provided poor grazing for sheep. The sandy soils, that had not attracted Anglian settlers, could not be cultivated profitably by traditional methods. Rainfall is relatively low (0.5 in. per year) and what rain falls soon drains away. Further, these light, arid soils tend to blow in strong winds. By 1790, however, the local landowners, notably the Bridgman - Simpson family of Babworth Hall, had the will, the inclination, and the capital to enclose the land, create large compact farms, and introduce new techniques.
